statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Missouri 77, Houston 61
article.story: COLUMBIA, Mo. (AP) -- After a long silence, Missouri's offense got revved up. Linas Kleiza had 19 points and 14 rebounds and the Tigers outscored Houston 20-1 over a 6½ minute span that began near the end of the first half of a 77-61 victory over Houston in the second round of the Guardians Classic on Tuesday night. "We can score in bunches," coach Quin Snyder said. "We are capable of going on runs." He'll tolerate the dry spells, too, because it's been only two games and Missouri is rebuilding after losing three starters. "It's like a poll of two people, you don't know right now," Snyder said. "I think we've got guys that can only get better with playing experience and we can only get better as a team." Missouri (2-0) made only one basket in more than 11 minutes and fell behind by five points earlier in the first half. The Tigers had little trouble scoring the rest of the game, shooting 50 percent and going 12-for-23 from 3-point range. Missouri hit only three of its first 18 from long range in the opening round against Brown. "Give Missouri credit, they came out to play and they played very well," Houston coach Tom Penders said. "They didn't take us lightly. Obviously, that wasn't the same team that played Brown." Thomas Gardner scored all but three of his 18 points in the second half for the Tigers, who advanced to the semifinals on Tuesday in Kansas City. Jimmy McKinney had 16 points and Jason Conley 14, and Kleiza added five assists. Missouri, which struggled to get past Brown 68-60 in the first round, will play Creighton in the semifinals. Houston was added to the field as an at-large bid and will play Ohio State, also on Tuesday. "I want them to face good, stiff competition," Penders said. "I don't believe in playing creampuffs and fattening up on that stuff." Andre Owens had 16 points and Lanny Smith 14 for Houston (1-1), which last faced Missouri in 1982. Houston rallied from a 10-point second half deficit in the first round against Sam Houston State for its first season-opening victory since 1999, but never threatened a repeat comeback. The Cougars led 29-24 with 3:47 left in the first half before the roof caved in. Conley had a 3-pointer at the end of the half and another at the start of the second half of the run that gave Missouri a comfortable 44-30 lead with 15:30 to play. The lead grew to as many as 21 points later in the half, a 62-41 bulge with 7:36 left. Missouri totaled four points during its first-half drought, a basket by Kevin Young and two free throws, before heating up. The Tigers have had double double outings in each of the first two games. Gardner had the first of his career on Monday with 19 points and 12 rebounds and has come off the bench both games. "In the first half I was a little over-excited and my shots were long," Gardner said. "In the second half I really got into the game, got my head into the game, and we stepped up on defense." Kleiza had three double doubles as a freshman last season and missed one in the opener by only one rebound. "It just shows that I play hard," Kleiza said. "If I have a double double, that's fine with me. If not, that's fine with me, too." The Missouri game was preceded Sam Houston State's 92-79 victory over Brown in a consolation, and the doubleheader drew attendance of 8,054 -- just over half-full in the new Paige Sports Arena. Snyder blamed the lack of interest on the games being played during the week. "People who come to our games come from all over the state," Snyder said. "I have a great friend in St. Louis that didn't come and I know he loves the team. "I'm not worried about that, I think the fans we did have were great."
